title: ASX to drop, US bond yields surge
summary: Australian shares are set to tumble more than 1 per cent amid broad selling in New York. US 10-year yield leaps above 1.5pc. $A sheds 1pc. VIX surges 37pc.
text: {'heading': ['Australian shares are poised to drop as the pace of repositioning moves accelerates on heightened fears of inflation, rising optimism about the US economic outlook and the potential for a much earlier than anticipated lift in interest rates.', 'ASX futures were down 97 points or 1.4 per cent to 6696 near 8am AEDT. The Aussie was 1.2 per cent lower. The Bloomberg dollar spot index gained 0.7 per cent.', 'Bitcoin was 1.8 per cent higher at $US49,070 near 8am AEDT on bitstamp.net.', 'In New York, all three major benchmarks tumbled. At the close, the Dow was down 600 points or 1.9 per cent. The S&P 500 was down 2.5 per cent, below the 3830 point mark. The Nasdaq was 3.5 per cent lower, its largest daily percentage fall in four months.', 'Tesla was 8.1 per cent lower, trading below $US685 a share. Facebook fell 3.6pc, Apple fell 3.5pc, Amazon fell 3.2pc, Alphabet fell 3.1pc. Microsoft lost 2.4pc. The NYSE FANG+ index slid 3.3 per cent, erasing almost all of February’s advance.', 'All 11 of the S&P 500’s industry sectors were lower, paced by consumer discretionary, information technology and communication services.', 'The yield on the US 10-year note was 11 basis points at 1.49 per cent at 4.31pm in New York; it earlier rose as high as 1.61 per cent. The five-year yield spiked to 0.81 per cent; the five-year yield has risen 40 basis points in the past month.', 'There was a sudden wave of selling after demand cratered at the Treasury’s 7-year note auction on Thursday (Friday AEDT), Bloomberg reported. Another wave roiled the bond market as afternoon trading progressed.', 'Australia’s counterpart yesterday surged 12 basis points to 1.73pc; Germany’s was 7 basis points higher at -0.23 per cent.', '“We’re certainly getting proof that when bond market sentiment turns, it can do so pretty violently and you’d better not get in the way,” Scotiabank’s Derek Holt said. “The Fed is strongly signalling it has no such intention of standing in front of this steamroller, just as should be the case.', '“We could continue to migrate much higher from here over time and it’s the fundamentals picture that is fully in charge of the curve versus a more transactional mindset. The curve slopes are behaving in a generally classic way so far given the outlook, with later stages to flatten the front-end still well ahead.”', 'Canada’s 10-year yield was up 14 basis points, Brazil’s climbed 15 basis points and Mexico’s increased 19 basis points.', '“We continue to be positive on stocks over bonds, but sentiment may be getting a little hot right now so we wouldn’t be surprised to see volatility pick-up,” LPL Financial strategist Ryan Detrick said.', '“Volatility is the cost of admission for stock investors, and getting caught up in the short-term headlines can cause investors to lose sight of their time horizon,” Mr Detrick also said.', 'The VIX was 35 per cent higher to 28.89.', '“The surge in the VIX is not welcome and rising VIX is a headwind for stocks,” Fundstrat Global’s Tom Lee said. “But do we see this as directionally signaling new lows? Given how cautious our clients have been (not ebullient), coupled with many ‘top callers’, coupled with improving economic visibility, we think this will prove to be a ‘rotational’ event.”', 'US equities dropped even as the outlook for the economy continues to improve.', 'Weekly jobless claims fell far more than expected; orders for durable goods rose last month, albeit at a slower pace than in December; and there was a slight upward revision in the estimate of fourth-quarter GDP growth.', 'Oxford Economics said: “Our US Recovery Tracker rose 1.2ppts to 81.9 in the week ended February 12 – its highest level since October. Improving health dynamics remained central to the upward tendency.“', 'Commodities markets were relatively quiet, though gold lost more of its lustre.', 'Oanda’s Edward Moya said he faster global bond yields rise, the sharper the fall is for gold. “The precious metal is having a rough 2021 and the only thing that can right the ship is if central banks thwart the trajectory of bond yields. The Fed will have plenty of opportunities to stem surging Treasury yields, but for now it seems they can be a little more patient.”', 'Mr Moya also said investors will wait to wait longer to see if skyrocketing bond yields threaten financial stability. “If financial conditions breakdown over the next couple of weeks, that could trigger a strong move by the Fed.', '“The surge in Treasury yields mostly likely can’t keep this pace up so gold should start to stabilise soon. If the bond selloff continues and gold does break critical support at the $US1750 level, technical selling could see this get another 5 per cent uglier.”'], "Today's agenda": ['Local: January private sector credit, February ABS business conditions and sentiments; NZ January trade balance, February ANZ consumer confidence', 'Overseas data: China February PMIs manufacturing and non-manufacturing; Japan January industrial production; US January personal income, spending and PCE Core, February Chicago PMI'], 'Market highlights': ['ASX futures down 97 points or 1.4 per cent to 6696 near 8am AEDT', 'AUD -1.2% to 78.71 US cents', 'Bitcoin on bitstamp.net +1.8% to $US49,070 near 8am AEDT', 'On Wall St: Dow -1.8% S&P 500 -2.5% Nasdaq -3.5%', 'In New York: BHP -2.1% Rio -1.7% Atlassian -3.1%', 'In Europe: Stoxx 50 -0.6% FTSE -0.1% CAC -0.2% DAX -0.7%', 'Spot gold -1.6% to $US1775.85/oz at 1.42pm New York time', 'Brent crude -0.8% to $US66.51 a barrel', 'US oil -0.4% to $US62.94 a barrel', 'Iron ore +0.9% to $US174.24 a tonne', '2-year yield: US 0.17% Australia 0.12%', '5-year yield: US 0.79% Australia 0.86%', '10-year yield: US 1.49% Australia 1.73% Germany -0.23%', 'US prices as of 4.31pm in New York'], "From today's Financial Review": ['Afterpay takes on the big banks: Afterpay boosted its customer numbers 80 per cent in the first half, and its merchant numbers by 73 per cent as users flock to its instalment payments service.', 'Chanticleer: Qantas shows the COVID-19 way: The largest half-year loss in the history of Qantas belies the fact that chief executive Alan Joyce has deftly steered the airline through the pandemic in good shape to ride the recovery.', 'Canberra Observed: How political pile-ons could get in the way of vaccine rollout: The point-scoring over vaccination bungles risks undermining confidence in the program we are relying on to get the economy back to normal.', 'End of lockdowns push up carbon emissions: Australia’s carbon emissions fell 4.4 per cent in the year to September, but were starting to rise as border and economies opened up.'], 'United States': ['The Australian riding shotgun with Elon: Robyn Denholm grew up working at her family’s Sydney petrol station. Now she’s back home steering Tesla from Australia, which she says could be a green energy superpower.', 'Tesla has told workers it will temporarily halt some production at its car assembly plant in California, Bloomberg reported.', 'Workers on a Model 3 production line in Fremont were told their line would be down from February 22 until March 7. They were advised to take vacation time, if they had it.', 'Twitter expects to double annual revenue to at least $US7.5 billion and reach 315 million users in 2023.', 'GameStop should buy online gambling company Esports Entertainment Group, Citron Research said; acquiring Esports would allow GameStop “to seamlessly both pivot away from its secularly declining retail business and monetise its customer database.”', 'Costco said it would raise the minimum wage for its hourly staff to $US16 per hour starting next week.', 'A majority of Americans support the idea of more than doubling the minimum wage to $US15 per hour, a Reuters/Ipsos poll showed. Democrats support an increase to $US15; Republicans oppose it.'], 'Europe': ['European shares ended lower on Thursday, as higher bond yields and volatility in US markets offset optimism about a euro zone economic recovery.', 'The pan-European STOXX 600 index settled 0.4pc lower after rising as much as 0.5pc.', 'Euro zone economic sentiment rose more than expected in February, buoyed by more optimism in industry, services and among consumers, boosting inflation expectations which have fed into higher bond yields in recent weeks.', 'Sectors such as healthcare, utilities and other staples, which are considered bond proxies, fell on the day amid continued pressure from higher yields.', 'But commodity-linked sectors were among the best performers, boosted by multi-year highs in crude oil and base metal prices.', 'Standard Chartered slipped 6.2pc after posting a drop in its annual profit.', 'Anheuser-Busch InBev, the world’s largest brewer, tumbled 6.2pc even as it reported a higher-than-expected core quarterly profit, while Bayer dropped 6.4pc after posting a drop in fourth-quarter core earnings due to competition in the North American agriculture market.'], 'Asia': ['China shares rebounded on Thursday, as strong gains in the property sector helped the market recover from sharp losses made a day earlier.', 'At the close, the Shanghai Composite index was up 0.6pc at 3585.05, while the blue-chip CSI300 index was ended 0.pc higher at 5469.56.', 'A notable change on the margins is that onshore household demand for equities has been stronger than our previously bullish outlook, with record onshore mutual fund raising,” said Wendy Liu, head of China strategy at UBS global research, revising up the year-end base case target for blue-chip CSI300 to 6100 from 5450 previously.', '“This is offsetting the headwind on valuation multiples owing to growth broadening out among listed companies and China’s monetary policies turning more neutral.”'], 'Currencies': ['Coinbase has filed papers with US regulators to become a publicly traded company as digital currencies continue to march toward mainstream acceptance.', 'The digital currency exchange is seeking a direct listing, which would allow company insiders and early investors to convert their stakes in Coinbase into publicly traded stock.', 'Interest rate jump tests RBA: Companies and governments face rising borrowing costs as the Reserve Bank fails to suppress bond yields and the strong Australian dollar, despite the central bank’s aggressive $3 billion of bond purchases on Thursday.', 'Fed needs to ignore ‘taper tantrums’ and let longer rates rise: Short-term financial market volatility might cause some sleepless nights, but the Fed could unleash the lending capacity of the traditional banking system by letting the yield curve steepen further.', 'NZ housing policy stand blows up the bond market: New Zealand’s bonds were sold-off savagely on Thursday after the RBNZ added housing to its policy remit. Bond managers think it will have no option but to raise interest rates to preserve affordability.'], 'Commodities': ['Global steel output rose 4.8pc in January, paced by a 6.8pc surge in China, according to monthly data from worldsteel. China produced an estimated 90.2 million metric tons of steel last month.', 'TD Securities does not see the price leap in commodities as the start of a supercycle: “...we think the evidence overwhelmingly argues that the recent strength in the complex is tied to cyclical tailwinds, resulting from a stronger-than-seasonal factory throughput in China, along with US stimulus which increased the impetus to produce consumer goods.', '“Meanwhile, speculative appetite into commodities is surging, fuelled by synchronous interest in the reflation trade, inflation-hedge assets, and the ‘supercycle’ narrative.”', 'If the rally is indeed tied to a cyclical overshoot, TD said it cautions that China still controls the short-term commodity cycle, and tailwinds are set to morph into headwinds later this year. “Deafening calls for a supercycle, combined with widespread reflation and inflation-hedging appetite are all conspiring to fuel a growth in positioning not before seen. It’s still too early to call for a supercycle, but with metals priced for perfection, a reversal could occur as early as this [Northern Hemisphere] summer.”'], 'Australian sharemarket': ['ASX firms 0.8pc as BHP hits a record, A2 plunges: The Australian sharemarket rallied on Thursday.', 'Pivot to virus winners drives record profit for Future Gen: The pivot to COVID-19 pandemic winners has helped the Future Generation Global Investment Company report its strongest operating profit on record.', 'What we learnt: A2 Milk, Flight Centre, Life360: A2 Milk longs for the past, Flight Centre gets on its recovery bike and Life360 tracks down a potential deal.']}
author: Timothy Moore

title: Dow, S&P 500 edge higher as Powell deflects inflation concern
summary: Australian shares are poised to open lower as investors wrestle with concerns about inflation. The Dow and S&P 500 end modestly positive after early drops.
text: {'heading': ['Australian shares are set to open lower as Wall Street struggled through its session amid conflicting narratives about the outlook for inflation.', 'ASX futures were down 25 points or 0.5 per cent to 6766 near 8am AEDT; they earlier fell near 80 points. The currency slipped 0.1 per cent; the yield on the US 10-year Treasury note was at 1.35 per cent near 4.40pm in New York.', 'Click here for the AFR’s profit season calendar.', 'In New York, stocks tumbled hard out of the opening gate, recovered somewhat and then reset lower again. By the close both the Dow and S&P 500 held very modest gains, while the Nasdaq slid 0.5 per cent.', 'While the Dow pared some of its afternoon rebound, it did retrace 360 points of losses incurred in the first half hour of the day. The S&P 500 experienced a similar up and down session as did the tech-heavy Nasdaq.', 'The Nasdaq had shed near 4 per cent to start the session.', '“The market open today sure felt like a mini-‘flash crash’ with stocks universally gapping down big,” Fundstrat Global’s Tom Lee said.', 'However Mr Lee said investors should hold their nerve. “We are steady buyers as we see multiple supports for stocks but stick with epicentre, they are under-owned, not crowded trades.”', 'Mr Lee is referring to those companies hit hardest by the pandemic including travel, financials, transportation and industrials.', 'Tesla, which earlier slid more than 5pc at one point, was 2.2 per cent lower on the day. Tesla has lost about 20 per cent of its value since the company said earlier this month that it had invested $US1.5 billion in bitcoin.', 'Bitcoin was down 11.6% to $US48,100 at 8.15am AEDT on bitstamp.net.', 'In written testimony to Congress, Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell said: “The economic recovery remains uneven and far from complete, and the path ahead is highly uncertain.”', 'In answering questions, Mr Powell made clear he was not concerned about the rise in bond yields or threats from inflation and that the Fed will be patient.', 'Mr Powell said it was important to determine what was behind the higher bond yields, namely expectations of a return to a more normal economy.', '“In a way, it’s a statement on confidence on the part of markets that we will have a robust and ultimately complete recovery,” he said.', 'Pantheon Macroeconomics’ view on Mr Powell: “The Fed’s core view is that the quarter-century long period of low inflation will continue.”', 'It also said, it is pretty sure “that Mr Powell and his colleagues are not going to panic and change their tone at the first hint of stronger growth or higher inflation in the spring”.', 'Mr Powell “has consistently made the point in recent months that returning the economy to a position where the Fed’s objectives are in reach will take time, given the starting point”, Pantheon said.', 'Benchmark copper on the London Metal Exchange was 1.2pc higher at $US9205 a tonne at 1700 GMT, having earlier reached $US9305, the highest since August 2011.'], "Today's agenda": ['Local: Fourth quarter construction work done and wage price index', 'Overseas data: Reserve Bank of New Zealand policy decision; US January new home sales, Fed boss Jerome Powell’s second day of semi-annual testimony to Congress'], 'Market highlights': ['ASX futures down 25 points or 0.5 per cent to 6766 near 8am AEDT', 'AUD -0.1% to 79.11 US cents', 'Bitcoin on bitstamp.net -11.6% to $US48,100 at 8.15am AEDT', 'On Wall St: Dow +0.1% S&P 500 +0.1% Nasdaq -0.5%', 'In New York: BHP +1.4% Rio +0.2% Atlassian +0.2%', 'In Europe: Stoxx 50 -0.3% FTSE +0.2% CAC +0.2% DAX -0.6%', 'Spot gold -0.1% to $US1807.10/oz at 1.02pm New York time', 'Brent crude +0.03% to $US65.26 a barrel', 'US oil -0.2% to $US61.58 a barrel', 'Iron ore -1.7% to $US173.05 a tonne', '2-year yield: US 0.11% Australia 0.11%', '5-year yield: US 0.57% Australia 0.76%', '10-year yield: US 1.35% Australia 1.56% Germany -0.32%', 'US prices near 4.40pm in New York'], "From today's Financial Review": ['Interest rate rise bets for 2022 ‘spook’ market: Interest rate traders are betting the first post-COVID-19 increase in the RBA’s cash rate will occur late next year, amid bullish sentiment on vaccines and a more than $2 trillion Biden spending stimulus.', 'Chanticleer: Seek empowers Ian Narev’s makeover: From the dumped CEO of Commonwealth Bank of Australia to boss of one of our most successful tech platforms - Ian Narev is a man remade.', 'Commodities in most bullish environment in a decade: Fund managers say it’s the most bullish environment for commodities they’ve seen in more than a decade, with base metals surging to multi-year highs and oil making one of its strongest starts to any year on record.', 'Commodity supercycle or short-term squeeze?: The bulls are proclaiming we’re in the early stage of a new commodity supercycle, but more cautious observers warn the run-up in commodity prices reflect temporary disruptions to supply.'], 'United States': ['Fed’s Powell: US economic recovery is ‘uneven’: “The economic recovery remains uneven and far from complete, and the path ahead is highly uncertain,” the top US central bank said.', 'The Conference Board said its consumer confidence index rose to a reading of 91.3 this month from 88.9 in January. Economists polled by Reuters had forecast the index nudging up to a reading of 90.', 'Wedbush on Tesla’s stock price drop: “The last few days have been nasty for Tesla shares as the company’s stock continues to sell off for two core reasons in our opinion. First is related to bitcoin, as since diving into the deep end of the pool with its $US1.5 billion bitcoin purchase last month for both good and bad the company’s stock is now heavily tied to this digital currency.”', '“Second, Tesla stopping sales of its lowest price Model Y coupled by continued price cuts have led to Street demand concerns as the bears come out of hibernation mode. We never viewed this Model Y version as moving the needle and continued price cuts has been part of the overall Tesla strategy over the past year and we do not expect that to change.”', 'Wedbush said its “‘buckle up the seat belt time’ again for Tesla’s stock with more volatility on the horizon. We maintain our $US950 price target and $US1250 bull case. We maintain our neutral rating”.'], 'Europe': ['UK stocks closed higher on Tuesday, bucking the trend in Europe as optimism around an economic recovery led by plans to ease restrictions in Britain offset a spike in the domestic unemployment rate.', 'After falling as much 1.7pc, the commodity-heavy FTSE 100 ended 0.2pc higher after British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said he was very optimistic that all COVID-19 restrictions in England would end on June 21.', 'The mid-cap FTSE 250 gained 0.4pc.', 'British Airways owner IAG gained 2.0pc, while easyJet, Wizz Air and Cineworld gained between 1.8pc and 9.5pc.', 'Summer holiday bookings surged by as much as 600pc after Britain laid out plans to gradually relax coronavirus restrictions.', 'HSBC Holdings edged up 0.8pc, alongside other banking stocks, despite lowering its long-term profitability target.', 'Barclays and Lloyds Banking Group rose 3.1pc and 2pc respectively.', 'However, the benchmark euro zone stock index was down 0.4pc, with tech stocks leading declines for a second straight session as they retreated further from 20-year highs.', 'Among individual movers, HSBC Holdings dropped 0.8pc after its annual profits fell sharply due to the pandemic, while it unveiled a revised strategy focused mainly on wealth management in Asia.', 'Swiss packaging firm SIG Combibloc Group bottomed out the STOXX 600 after its annual core earnings missed estimates.', 'German health care group Fresenius slipped after it narrowed its 2021 sales growth forecast and said it would launch a cost-cutting program, while cement-maker HeidelbergCement dropped 2.3pc even after preliminary results showed core profit was up 6% last year.', 'French energy group Total gained more than 2pc after it agreed to sell stakes in some wind and solar farms to Credit Agricole Assurances and Banque des Territoires.'], 'Asia': ['China stocks closed lower in volatile trading on Tuesday, after a sharp correction the previous session, amid worries over policy tightening and lofty valuations.', 'The blue-chip CSI300 index fell 0.3pc to 5579.67, after logging the biggest daily drop in nearly seven months on Monday. The Shanghai Composite Index slid 0.2pc to 3636.36.', '“The trend of China’s policy tightening is quite evident and definite, though the PBOC would refrain from sudden and fast tightening with an aim to provide stability for the market,” said Zheng Zichun, an analyst with AVIC Securities.', '“We now favour cyclical companies, including those in petroleum and chemical, nonferrous metals, digging and financial industries,” he said.', 'In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index rose 1.0pc to 30,632.64, while the China Enterprises Index gained 0.1pc to 11,909.63.', 'The Hang Seng financials index climbed 2.1pc to lead the gains. The index is up 12.3pc so far this year. The Hang Seng energy index advanced 2.6pc as oil prices jumped.', 'Galaxy Entertainment Group surged as much as 12pc to a record high of $HK78.20, the top mover among Macau’s gaming stocks that advanced on report of strong rebound in gaming revenue during the Chinese New Year.'], 'Currencies': ['RBA will defend its credibility: When the RBA’s trading desk wades back into government bond markets this week, expect it to step in more aggressively to defend its word.', 'ING on the European Central Bank: “For the time being, the ECB will focus on taming any inflationary expectations and speculation with words. However, the difficulty of this challenge is reflected in the fact that over the last few weeks the ECB has come up with a series of verbal interventions, warning against premature normalising of monetary policy, focusing on financing conditions, talking about real rates and finally emphasising nominal bond yields.', '“All of this makes it harder to read the ECB’s reaction function but at least it shows that the ECB has become aware of its newest challenges. In our view, the ECB could eventually move towards a kind of (real) yield curve control. Until then, one thing is clear, staying on the sidelines has become less comfortable for the central bank in recent days.”'], 'Commodities': ['TD Securities sees ‘cyclical overshoot’ not a ‘supercycle’: “Cascading tailwinds for demand have are joining forces with a growing supply risk premium to deliver sharp returns, while speculative demand offers further support, with open interest for copper options rising sharply.', '“While calls of a metals supercycle are growing louder, the evidence suggests we’re in the midst of a cyclical overshoot with speculative effects on price action piling up.”', 'Bank of America said oil has moved “past” its earlier forecast: “So we now lift our average Brent crude oil price forecast to $US60/bbl in 2021, compared to $US50/bbl prior. We also believe prices could temporarily spike to $US70/bbl in 2Q21.', '“Yet, one big change relative to our June 2020 expectations is that OPEC+ has extended its supply cut deal into 1Q21 and removed an extra 180mn bbl from the market, creating more spare capacity. Separately, the big Texas freeze in the past week should reduce global inventories by an additional 50mn barrels, further supporting prices.”', 'One oil market risk, according to BofA: “The biggest short-term downside risk to oil prices may come from a new Iran nuclear deal, as a new arrangement could bring 2mn b/d into the market in short order.”', 'Shanghai Dalu Futures, a brokerage on the Shanghai Futures Exchange, has amassed a $US1 billion long position in copper contracts within just four days, bourse data showed.', 'The little-known brokerage boosted its copper long positions by more than 800pc to emerge as the top long position holder of the May, June and July ShFE copper contracts, visible ShFE data showed.', 'In doing so, it added 19,774 copper lots to its copper position in the April-July contracts, equivalent to 6.7 billion yuan ($US1.04 billion) based on the closing price of ShFE’s most-active April contract on Tuesday.'], 'Australian sharemarket': ['ASX firms 0.9pc even as tech stocks take a hit: The S&P/ASX 200 Index gained 58.3 points or 0.9 per cent on Tuesday, bitcoin quit its record breaking run, and Afterpay, Xero and the rest of the tech sector were dealt losses.', 'Equity investors should stop fretting about rising interest rates: Rather than fear the bond market, equity investors can prosper from a stronger economy that boosts earnings and, yes, also leads to higher interest rates. It’s called a recovery.', 'Fine balance between optimism and pessimism in asset pricing: Central banks are not only forcefully anchoring interest rates but they are pushing asset prices as a means to an end.', 'Platinum performance fees return: Investment performance added $3.26 billion to its funds under management, which was ruled off at December 31 at $23.6 billion, more than offsetting $1 billion of outflows during the half.']}
author: Timothy Moore

title: ASX to slip as commodities extend gains
summary: Australian shares are set to open lower as tech selling accelerated into the close in New York, dragging the Nasdaq sharply lower.
text: {'heading': ['Australian shares are poised to open lower, as selling in Wall Street offset rising prices for commodities and optimism about the global economic outlook.', 'Gold, oil, iron ore as well as copper, nickel, aluminium and lead advanced overnight.', 'ASX futures down 13 points or 0.2 per cent to 6700 near 8am AEDT; they had been 15 higher at 7am AEDT. The currency was up 0.6pc.', 'Click here for the AFR’s profit season calendar.', 'In New York, US stocks were mixed with the Dow barely higher and both the S&P 500 and Nasdaq lower. The Nasdaq slumped 2.5 per cent, with a late surge in selling extending losses.', 'Techs were hit by a selling wave: Apple -3pc, Microsoft -2.7pc, Amazon -2.1pc. Tesla slid 8.6pc. The US listed shares of Atlassian tumbled 6.7pc.', 'The yield on the US 10-year note edged up 3 basis points to 1.37 per cent; its Australian counterpart was at 1.64pc. Westpac this week lifted its year-end 2021 forecast for the Aussie 10-year yield to 1.9pc and its year-end 2022 forecast to 2.4pc.', '“We expect that higher rate profile to persist right out to end 2024 when we see the US 10 year bond rate settling at around 3pc (reaching a sustainable peak before the first rate hike by the Fed),” Westpac said. “That next cycle can be expected to be more gradual than previous cycles.”', 'As for the outlook for US rates, investors await Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell’s semi-annual testimony to Congress starting on Tuesday (Wednesday AEDT).', '“Powell will likely reiterate they are nowhere near their employment and inflation targets,” Oanda’s Edward Moya said in a note: “The path of rates won’t change this year, with the earliest that some economists see a potential move up in rates being next January.', '“Since financial conditions are tightening and with wage pressures remaining nonexistent, that should keep inflation fears from getting out of control. The economic data has been improving but remains inconsistent and that is all Powell needs to keep his ultra-accommodative stance.”', 'Bitcoin was near 7.6pc lower at $US53,790 near 7am AEDT on bitstamp.net; it earlier briefly to below $US49,700. Tesla has earned “roughly” $US1 billion from its bitcoin bet.', 'Metals continued to be actively traded. Gold leapt back above $US1800 an ounce; benchmark oil was near 3pc higher. US oil was up more than 3pc.', 'In London, base metals continue to reset multiyear highs. Benchmark copper surged as high as $US9269.50 in London trading and premiums for quickly deliverable metal on the London Metal Exchange hit two-year highs, suggesting supplies are tight.', 'Nickel was trading above $US20,000 a tonne for the first time since 2014. Aluminium gained 1.9pc to $US2172, earlier hitting its highest since October 2018 at $US2177.50. Both lead and zinc also touched highs last reached in 2019.', '“Speculative interest has surged in a number of commodities, as price momentum has fuelled near-term bullishness,” Continuum Economics said in a note.', 'As per the level of speculation, Marex Spectron said LME copper net spec long has swiftly expanded to 50pc of OI as at last Thursday, a level not seen since September 2017. That year the long reached 58pc of OI.', '“Expectations of an inflationary environment have historically led the commodity price cycle and with the US 10 year bond yield continuing its ascent, this should be monitored for chinks in our base metals pricing armour particularly with the Fed’s Powell testifying in front of Congress” this week, Marex also said.'], "Today's agenda": ['Local: International merchandise trade January; NZ retail sales volumes fourth quarter', 'Overseas data: UK December ILO unemployment rate; US December FHFA house prices and S&P CoreLogic CS house prices, February consumer confidence index and Richmond Fed index'], 'Market highlights': ['ASX futures down 13 points or 0.2 per cent to 6700 near 8am AEDT', 'AUD +0.6% to 79.16 US cents', 'Bitcoin -7.5% $US53,874.77 at 7.04am AEDT', 'On Wall St: Dow +0.1% S&P 500 -0.8% Nasdaq -1.6%', 'In New York: BHP +1.9% Rio +0.4% Atlassian -6.7%', 'In Europe: Stoxx 50 -0.4% FTSE -0.2% CAC -0.1% DAX -0.3%', 'Spot gold +1.4% to $US1809.07/oz at 1.01pm New York time', 'Brent crude +2.8% to $US64.69 a barrel', 'US oil +3.1% to $US61.05 a barrel', 'Iron ore +1.4% to $US175.96 a tonne', '2-year yield: US 0.11% Australia 0.12%', '5-year yield: US 0.60% Australia 0.79%', '10-year yield: US 1.37% Australia 1.64% Germany -0.34%', 'US prices near 5pm in New York'], "From today's Financial Review": ['Crown hit by royal commission', 'Embattled casino giant Crown Resorts faces full-scale inquiries in two states after Victoria joined Western Australia in launching a royal commission into the gambling giant.', 'Crown royal commission deepens Coonan’s woes', 'Chanticleer: BoQ’s chance to shed mediocrity: Bank of Queensland will become Australia’s sixth-largest bank following its $1.3 billion merger with ME Bank. Bigger is not necessarily better unless CEO George Frazis can fix long-standing problems in both banks.', 'Sydney man arrested over alleged bitcoin money-laundering scheme: A Sydney man is facing drug and money-laundering charges as police allege the man tried to get criminals to convert nearly $5.5 million in cash into bitcoin.'], 'United States': ['Climbing Treasury yields and prospects of rising inflation triggered valuation concerns, hitting shares of high-flying growth companies.', '“There’s little new money going into the market. It is like everyone has bought in and, at some point, there’s an exhaustion of buyers and the market tends to come down a little bit,” said David Keller, chief market strategist at StockCharts.com.', '“The market is recognising the general euphoric sentiment conditions that we’ve had.”', 'Value stocks have outperformed growth shares in February, with investors betting on a rebound in industrial activity and a pick up in consumer demand as countries roll out vaccines to tame the pandemic.'], 'Europe': ['The pan-European STOXX 600 index settled 0.4pc down after dropping as much as 1pc, led by declines in technology companies and retail stocks.', 'A recent rise in sovereign debt yields on forecasts for rising inflation has weighed on risk-driven assets because the higher yields offer safer returns.', 'But yields in the euro zone dropped after European Central Bank president Christine Lagarde said the bank was closely monitoring rising borrowing costs, which could point towards future ECB intervention in debt markets.', 'The tech sector hit a 20-year high last week and Mirabaud analyst Neil Campling attributed recent losses to profit-taking after a “period of positive price action”.', 'Travel and leisure stocks strengthened after British Prime Minister Boris Johnson set out a phased plan to end the country’s COVID-19 lockdown.', 'The FTSE 100 also trimmed losses through the day, with British Airways owner IAG jumping more than 7pc after raising its total liquidity by £2.45 billion.', 'Security company G4S, however, tumbled nearly 10pc after Canada’s GardaWorld said it would not raise its takeover, handing victory to Allied Universal in their months-long bid battle.'], 'Asia': ['China capital control changes designed to fuel Hong Kong IPO market: China’s regulators consider making it easier for its citizens to invest in Hong Kong’s booming IPO market. Limits on how much individuals can take out of the country will remain.', 'China’s blue-chip index posted its biggest daily drop in nearly seven months on Monday after touching record highs last week, as investors fretted over high stock valuations and the risk of policy tightening.', 'The blue-chip CSI300 index slumped 3.1pc to close at 5597.33 points, its biggest daily percentage drop since July 24, 2020. The Shanghai Composite index fell 1.5pc to 3642.44 points.', 'Despite Monday’s slump, valuations remain near record highs and some analysts expect earnings to stay strong on a cyclical recovery.', '“We could see a sharper rotation into cyclical stocks like banks, materials and energy, with tech shares remaining strong following very robust performance (year-to-date),” said Carlos Casanova, senior economist for Asia at Union Bancaire Privee.', 'At the close of trade, the Hang Seng index was down 324.90 points or 1.1pc at 30,319.83, reversing gains marked earlier in the day. The Hang Seng China Enterprises index fell 1.8pc to 11,893.68.', 'Tencent Holdings was the biggest drag in the Hang Seng index, falling 3.7pc and pulling the IT sector 4.4pc lower. The IT index hit a record high last week.'], 'Currencies': ['The pound hit fresh three-year highs against the US dollar as bullish investors bet on the UK’s vaccination rollout bringing about an economic recovery and Prime Minister Boris Johnson set out a schedule for easing the lockdown.', 'Sterling has risen 2.9pc against the US dollar in 2021 and its rapid gains have led to talk of a possible correction. Speculators added to their net long position in the currency for the third week running in the week to February 16, CFTC positioning data showed. The market is at its most bullish in one year.'], 'Commodities': ['Benchmark copper on the LME was up 1.9pc at $US9075.50 a tonne at 1710 GMT, after earlier touching $US9269.50. The premium for cash copper over the LME three-month contract rose as high as $US49.50 a tonne, the most since March 2019.', 'Prices are up about 7pc since China, the biggest consumer, returned on Thursday from its Lunar New Year holiday, taking gains to 16pc this year after a 26pc rise in 2020.', 'In contrast, coking coal and coke futures on the Dalian Commodity Exchange plunged on Monday, as some mills attempt to lower purchase prices of the steelmaking ingredients due to tight steel profit margins in China.', '“The uneven profit distribution is the main drive for steel producers to crack down coke prices,” Sinosteel wrote in a note, adding that profit at sample coking plants were at historical highs last week while raw material costs for blast furnaces continue to climb.', 'The most actively traded coking coal futures for May delivery, slumped nearly 6pc to 1487 yuan ($US230.07) per tonne and closed down 4.8pc.', 'Coke futures were down as much as 4.7pc, the biggest daily percentage loss since January 12. It ended 4pc lower at 2617 yuan per tonne.'], 'Australian sharemarket': ['ASX dips 0.2pc but travel stocks soar with vaccine rollout: The ASX sagged on Monday, as the market digested another slew of first-half financial results but travel stocks surged as Australia’s vaccine program kicked off.', 'ASX dividends to hit $73b as it rains upgrades: Corporate Australia will pay out $73 billion in dividends in 2020-21, after the biggest upgrade to payouts in 20 years. JPMorgan calls it the start of a dividend ‘super cycle’.']}
author: Timothy Moore

title: ASX to slip, Wall St steady, $A surges
summary: Australian shares set to extend Friday’s losses to start the week. $A leap puts US79¢ on the radar. Reporting season peak ahead.
text: {'heading': ['Australian shares are set to start the week with modest losses, extending Friday’s retreat.', 'ASX futures were down 11 points or 0.2 per cent to 6721; the S&P/ASX 200 Index tumbled 92.1 points, or 1.3 per cent, on Friday.', 'A slew of earnings are set for Monday including, Amaysim, Bluescope Steel, Costa Group, LendLease, McGrath, Nufarm and Platinum Asset Management. Click here for our reporting season calendar.', 'In contrast, the dollar spiked more than 1 per cent, putting US79¢ on the radar as base metals, in particular copper, and iron ore continue to lure investors on optimism about Chinese demand and the prospect for accelerating global growth.', 'The dollar spot index slipped 0.3 per cent; the Bloomberg dollar spot index was 0.2 per cent lower. The yield on the US 10-year note rose 4 basis points to 1.34 per cent; it is 25 basis points higher over the past month.', 'Shares closed mixed in New York on Friday there as the latest wave of record resets lost momentum. Still bulls are not throwing in the towel just yet.', 'Tim Hayes, chief investment strategist at Ned Davis Research, is particularly bullish: “We are increasing our recommended equity allocation to the maximum of 70 per cent, the fourth and final in a series of upgrades that started when we shifted from underweight to marketweight last June.', '“Getting in line with the current intra-month estimate of our Global Balanced Account Model, we are shifting 5 per cent from bonds to equities. And in response to the model’s indicator signals that are calling for shortening duration, we are moving 5 per cent from bonds to cash.”', 'Mr Hayes said the S&P 500 has now advanced for 72 days without a 5 per cent correction and 227 days without a 10 per cent decline, far beyond the secular bear means of 31 and 91 days respectively and increasingly consistent with the secular bull means of 84 and 331 days respectively.', '“With the secular bull resuming, the rally could be expected to continue for another 878 days before it would reach the mean number of days without a 20 per cent decline in a secular bull,” Mr Hayes said.', 'LPL Financial’s Ryan Detrick also is optimistic: “While pockets of weakness remain, the market is more concerned with where the economic conditions will be, not where they are currently.”', 'The major US indices are masking the real strength in equities, Fundstrat Global’s Tom Lee said, adding that last week saw a dramatic rotation into cyclically sensitive stocks such as energy and financials amid selling in technology and health care.', 'Mr Lee said the top might be in for growth stocks: the VIX is falling, commodities are strong, economic data remains strong and market watchers are turning cautious.'], "Today's agenda": ['Local: NZ credit card spending January', 'Overseas data: Euro zone IFO business climate February survey; US Chicago Fed national activity index and Leading index January, Dallas Fed index February'], 'Market highlights': ['ASX futures down 11 points or 0.2 per cent to 6721', 'AUD +1.3% to 78.69 US cents', 'On Wall St: Dow flat S&P 500 -0.2% Nasdaq +0.1%', 'In New York: BHP +0.4% Rio +2.2% Atlassian +0.7%', 'In Europe: Stoxx 50 +0.9% FTSE +0.1% CAC +0.8% DAX +0.8%', 'Spot gold +0.5% to $US1784.25/oz', 'Brent crude -2% to $US62.66 a barrel', 'US oil -2.8% to $US58.84 a barrel', 'Iron ore -0.9% to $US173.55 a tonne', '2-year yield: US 0.10% Australia 0.12%', '5-year yield: US 0.58% Australia 0.66%', '10-year yield: US 1.34% Australia 1.43% Germany -0.31%'], "From today's Financial Review": ['PM’s vaccination kicks off national rollout: The Morrison government, business and health experts are using the vaccine rollout to put pressure on premiers to end snap statewide lockdowns and border closures.', 'Like a mafia sting, inside the biggest insider trading case: Christopher Hill doesn’t like using the word “betrayed”, but that’s what happened when he disclosed secret jobs data from his employer to university pal Lukas Kamay.', 'ACCC clears Bank of Queensland deal with ME: Chairman Rod Sims paves the way for BoQ’s acquisition of ME after finding there was little evidence a merger would lessen competition.'], 'United States': ['Wall Street little changed as cyclicals shine, big tech falls: Financials, materials and energy, along with industrials, rose more than 1 per cent. The S&P 1500 airlines index also soared, with post-pandemic travel in focus.', 'IHS Markit’s flash US manufacturing PMI dropped to 58.5 in the first half of this month from a final reading of 59.2 in January. Extreme weather in large parts of the United States was one reason. The data was in line with economists’ forecasts.', 'Bank of America sees three opportunities within financials: “Our top sector for 2021, financials, remained #1 in our tactical quantitative framework for the third straight month. But this time, it ranked the highest on all three metrics: relative EPS revisions, relative price momentum and relative valuation.', '“A perfect score for a sector rarely happens (only 19 instances out of 220 months in history) and this is the first time for financials, suggesting the best backdrop for the sector in history.', '“Rising rates, potential stimulus, reopening, resumed buybacks, strong earnings, etc. all point to a strong year for financials. Within Financials, Consumer Finance, Banks, and Capital Markets screen as Opportunities.”', 'Bank of Montreal last week revised its US GDP growth forecast for 2021 higher this week by a full point to 6 per cent: “the key factors behind the revision were: 1) the growing prospects for an even larger-than-expected fiscal support package (ie, well above our earlier assumption of just under $US1 trillion) and, 2) more signs that the US economy was much more resilient than expected at the start of the year.', '“Most of the upward revision is piled into the opening months of 2021, so our 2022 call holds steady at a still-solid 4 per cent. Quick reminder: a 6 per cent growth rate would be the strongest annual gain since 1984, albeit following the deepest annual decline (-3.5 per cent) in the postwar period.”'], 'Europe': ['Euro zone shares rose on Friday, marking a third week of gains, as data showed factory activity in February jumped to a three-year high, while upbeat quarterly earnings boosted confidence in a broader economic recovery.', 'The euro zone index was up 0.9 per cent, with strong earnings from companies such as Acciona and Hermes brewing some optimism over an eventual economic recovery.', 'The pan-European STOXX 600 index rose 0.5 per cent, as regional factory activity was seen reaching a three-year high on strong demand for manufactured goods at home and overseas.', 'Another reading showed the euro zone’s current account surplus widened in December on a rise in trade surplus and a narrower deficit in secondary income.', 'Still, the STOXX 600 marked small gains for the week, having dropped for the past three sessions as investor concern grew over rising inflation and a rocky COVID-19 vaccine rollout.', 'But basic resources stocks outpaced their peers this week with a 7 per cent jump, as improving industrial activity across the globe drove up commodity prices.', 'London’s FTSE 100 lagged regional bourses on Friday due to a slump in January retail sales and as the pound jumped to its highest against the dollar in nearly three years.', 'French car maker Renault tumbled more than 4 per cent after posting a record annual loss of €8 billion.'], 'Asia': ['China’s blue-chip index recouped earlier losses to end higher on Friday, helped by gains in infrastructure and securities stocks, though it posted weekly losses.', 'The blue-chip CSI300 index edged up 0.2 per cent to 5778.84, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.6 per cent to 3696.17. For the holiday-shortened week, CSI eased 0.5 per cent, while SSEC firmed 1.1 per cent.', 'In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index ended 0.2 per cent firmer at 30,644.73, while the China Enterprises Index gained 0.5 per cent to 12,106.77 points. For the week, HSI firmed 1.6 per cent, while HSCE added 1.9 per cent, both posted their third consecutive weekly gains.', 'Leading the gains on Friday, the Hang Seng materials index climbed 3.1 per cent, having climbed 15.5 per cent in its best week since April 2015.', 'Telecommunications firms also advanced with an 11 per cent jump for the week.'], 'Currencies': ['NDR’s Joseph Kalish said bond markets may have sold off too fast. “Shorter-term, we may have gotten a bit overdone. Optimism and complacency from Fed support is fading fast, amid strong downside momentum. In fact, the downside momentum has just moved into the extreme zone on our index. Moreover, European inflation expectations remain on the cusp of breaking out. A decisive upside breakout would clear the way for higher yields.”', 'Why the market has suddenly woken up to inflation: The mantra of ‘lower for longer’ is coming under pressure as investors realise the potential damage inflation could inflict on complacent portfolios.', 'Bitcoin extended its rally in New York on Friday.', '“If you really believe there’s a store of value in bitcoin, then there’s still a lot of upside,” said John Wu, president of AVA Labs, an open-source platform for creating financial applications using blockchain technology.', '“If you look at gold, it has a market cap $US9 or $US10 trillion. Even if bitcoin gets to half of gold’s market cap, that’s still growth of 4X, or $US200,000. So I don’t know when it stops rising,” he added.'], 'Commodities': ['Copper jumped to its highest in more than nine years in London on Friday and logged its third straight weekly gain as tight supplies and bullish sentiment towards base metals continued after the Chinese New Year.', 'Benchmark copper on the London Metal Exchange added 4.4 per cent to $US8930 a tonne by 1723 GMT. The metal used in power and construction touched a peak of $US8995, its highest since September 2011.', '“The return of the Chinese market post the Lunar New Year has seen some renewed interest in base metals,” said Gianclaudio Torlizzi, a partner at consultancy T-Commodity in Milan.', '“The very short term for copper is bullish, but we are in the latest phase of a rally and we would look to short the area closer to $US9000.”', 'Inventories of copper in warehouses registered with the LME are near 2005 lows at 75,700 tonnes. Cancelled warrants - metal earmarked for delivery - account for about 39 per cent and further fuelled concerns about tight supply on the LME market.', 'The premium for cash copper over the three-month contract doubled to $US40 a tonne, its highest since September.', 'Fefferies Financial Group boosted their FY2021 earnings estimates for shares of Rio Tinto. Analyst C. Lafemina now anticipates that the mining company will post earnings of $US9.99 per share for the year, up from a previous forecast of $US9.84.', 'Iron ore eased on Friday on news of higher than expected Chinese steel inventories.', 'Stocks of the five major finished steel products held by the 184 Chinese mills under Mysteel consultancy’s regular survey grew by a sharp 46.1 per cent during February 4-17.', 'Consumption among steel end-users stagnated during the February 11-17 holiday while mills continued to produce during the break, Mysteel reported.'], 'Australian sharemarket': ['ASX dragged lower as blue chips weigh: The Australian sharemarket fell for a second week running despite a number of strong earnings results and dividend surprises, with a heavy sell-off on Friday.', 'Even earnings can’t reassure jittery markets: This reporting season has fund managers on edge, as they grapple with unexpected market reactions to results while keeping a wary eye on bond yields.', 'Chanticleer: Blue-chip profit resurgence far from over: Blue-chip companies led the profit season surprises this week, confirming an economic recovery that is likely just getting started.', 'Dividend bonanza as business leads the recovery: A combination of factors is pointing to growing evidence that the market sees the surging economy as more than a short-term event.', 'Corporate Australia is getting back to good health: More than halfway through the season, corporate Australia is shrugging off the gloom of the COVID-19 pandemic, delivering improving profits and looking to the future with more optimism.']}
author: Timothy Moore
